snippet: Owners of small dirt tracks often cannot afford top-of-the-line safety equipment, and with so many sanctioning bodies, there is no standard for safety regulations.
abstract: Minor league of dirt track racing is less regulated and less safe than regulated series like Nascar and IndyCar; most of nation's roughly 500 dirt tracks have no safety barriers along the walls, and drivers race without the interior head restraints that major tracks require; longtime Nascar driver Jason Leffler, killed during a sprint car race in New Jersey, is at least the sixth driver to die in a crash on a dirt track in last 13 months

byline.original: By MARY PILON and VIV BERNSTEIN

lead_paragraph: Owners of small dirt tracks often cannot afford top-of-the-line safety equipment, and with so many sanctioning bodies, there is no standard for safety regulations.

headline.main: Danger Lurks in Dirt Track Racing
headline.print_headline: Danger Lurks in Dirt Track Racing
